awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Spiral Polynomial Division Multiplexing
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is to support rapidly growing wireless data usage with fixed available bandwidth through the provision of more robust synchronization. Modern high-speed communication is heavily dependent on precise synchronization between transmitters and receivers to enable efficient data throughput. This project pioneers an entirely novel technique based on ?Spiral Polynomial Division Multiplexing? (SPDM) to enable precise and efficient synchronization. It offers a new set of approaches for improving synchronization, with possible applications to any communication systems that face extreme spectral efficiency demands, or which are challenged by particularly difficult synchronization problems such as communication with high-speed vehicles such as trains. This project could lead to commercialization across a wide range of communication sectors including but not limited to wireless, mobile internet, unmanned vehicles, automotive, aviation, and Internet of Things. It has major potential applications in both civilian and defense applications. SPDM shows promise in providing more robust communications that are resistant to interference and jamming.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project addresses the problem of achieving very precise synchronization between a transmitter and receiver, while expending minimal power and bandwidth to do so. The research objective is to show that a new type of synchronization, based on SPDM, enables superior synchronization performance than is possible with previous methods. SPDM introduces a new way of combining, or multiplexing, signals based on orthogonality in the polynomial coefficient space. This results in a very large waveform design space, which can be bandlimited using polynomial convolution with a ?shaping polynomial?. Synchronization can be achieved within SPDM by checking for the time alignment which produces a ?reasonable result? when the shaping polynomial is deconvolved in the receiver, which can be a very sensitive test due to the special properties of SPDM polynomials. The research will involve systematically testing SPDM synchronization under a variety of conditions, examining performance data, and comparing against standard synchronization methods. It is anticipated that this research will show significant benefits for SPDM synchronization in at least some practically important situations, forming the basis for further research leading to deployment of SPDM-based systems.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit:

Astrapi is the pioneer of a new approach to communication, called Spiral Polynomial Division Multiplexing (SPDM). In Phase I, we developed an SPDM software research platform that allows us to systematically test polynomial-based symbol waveform design performance against Additive White Gaussian Noise (AWGN) and phase noise, and to test synchronization and signal detection algorithms. We used this to establish fundamental results related to SPDM technical viability and benefits. Astrapi laid the foundations for an innovative communication platform.

 In Phase I we showed how to transfer information using a continuously nonstationary spectrum, and established important properties such as how to synchronize between the transmitter and receiver. This opens a very rich and unexplored symbol waveform design space supporting optimization for specific communication challenges. Independently, SPDM makes use of new mathematics for signal transmission, called Instantaneous Spectral Analysis (ISA), which for the first time shows how to decompose arbitrary polynomials into a sum of sinusoids with continuously-varying amplitude. Classical communication theory finds an upper bound for channel capacity based in part on the sampling theorem, which through the use of the Fourier transform assumes sinusoids with constant amplitude over an evaluation period. SPDM opens the door to dramatic increases in spectral efficiency. Further, SPDM enables new tools for mitigating coherent interference through polynomial basis rotation and may be more robust against channel fading since it does not explicitly encode information in phase.

Broader impacts:

Successful commercialization of SPDM leading to higher spectral efficiency would enable communication service providers and operators to better utilize existing bandwidth – an expensive and finite resource limiting communication-related applications. Satellite networks are capacity and power constrained, and susceptible to increasing interference, yet their customers are demanding higher throughput. Existing available modulation approaches have reached the theoretical limit. That’s why the operators have to spend so much at the complete opposite end of the value chain to acquire spectrum rights or build expensive infrastructure to meet demand.  Successful commercialization of spiral modulation uniquely unleashes economic value in the physical layer and enhances the ability of communication network service providers to increase throughput also supports greatly improved Internet delivery to the majority of the world that currently does not have adequate service. Significant power savings may also be possible for mobile handsets, which would lower device costs while increasing performance.

Significant primary validation has established both the acute market pain and the large markets addressable by SPDM. Since beginning the Phase I work Astrapi has achieved significant advancement and interest in spiral modulation. Astrapi won the inaugural Startup Space Pitch competition and validated the business proposition at the SATELLITE 2017 conference, was accepted to the 2017 National Association of Broadcasters (NAB) Futures Lab Park Pilot program, invited to participate in the United States Patent and Trade Office select Site Experience Education (SEE) program, invited/presented to the Wireless Spectrum Research & Development (WSRD) Interagency Working Group, was named a 2016 EE Times Silicon 60 Emerging Companies to Watch list, and was accepted and presented at the IEEE Metrocon conference among others.

The scientific impact may be more profound. SPDM introduces new mathematics to communications, and represents a significant departure from all existing digital modulation approaches based upon sinusoids with constant amplitude over a symbol period. Academic and non-profit research institutions may develop research programs and technical publications arising from our research.

 Astrapi defines and controls an entirely new field – spiral modulation.  Spiral modulation addresses an acute problem - the spectrum crisis. The spectrum crisis is impacting four massive market opportunities for Astrapi – satellite, wireless, defense and IoT.
